title: 3 recent iPhone myths debunked: Charging, theft, and Face ID
content:

Your iPhone isnâ€™t a sudden theft risk

It all sounds very scary and serious, but itâ€™s still extremely rare. Maybe Apple should stop using your passcode as the security method for changing your Apple ID password, but otherwise, there are plenty of strong protections built into the iPhone.

There isnâ€™t a Face ID flaw

As if the fear and loathing about stolen iPhones wasnâ€™t enough, a whole other set of articles used The Wall Street Journal report to expose supposed holes in Face ID, including WRDW (â€œFace I.D. might not be as secure as you thinkâ€), Local 3 News in Tennessee (â€œHow thieves can steal your money using iPhoneâ€™s Face ID featureâ€) and even the NYC Office for the Prevention of Hate Crime, which advised iPhone users to disable Face ID when going out â€œto protect your phone and data.â€
